titleStmt.title: Minutes of Historical Advisory Committee Meeting, May 1993
HAC Meeting Minutes, 1993

div.head: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HISTORICAL DIPLOMATIC DOCUMENTATION MAY 20-21, 1993

item.p: Kenneth Rossman, Chief, Records Management, IM/IS/OIS/RA/RD
John Pereira, Chief, Historical Review Group

row.cell: Report by the Historian on the Status of the Foreign Relations series
John Fawcett Report on Presidential Libraries
Kenneth McDonald Report on CIA Historical staff
Discussion of Working Group Report on Opening of Department’s Records
Discussion of Publication of CIA Documentation
Report by John Pereira on CIA Declassification Activities
Discussion of Gaps in Documentation for LBJ Volumes
Discussion of Presidential Review Directive on Declassification

div.p: Advisory Committee chairman Warren Kimball called the meeting to order. Department Historian and Executive Secretary of the Advisory Committee William Slany informed the Committee that Deputy Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs Bennett Freeman, who had been assigned oversight for PA/HO, would join the Committee during lunch. Richard Boucher would speak to the Committee briefly during the afternoon session.

It was agreed that consideration of the minutes of the last meeting would be postponed until the revised copies were ready. Nelson suggested that the minutes should be modeled on the Gleason memos of NSC discussions, that is, that they should include the gist of the discussion without attempting to be verbatim. Kimball stated that he was satisfied with the existing format of the minutes.

In discussing the proposed agenda, Kimball noted that the time needed to discuss the Working Group Report that afternoon could not be predicted. He thought, if necessary, the subcommittee reports on Foreign Relations declassification matters could be succint, allowing more time to discuss the Working Group report, if necessary.

Slany pointed out that the agenda did not include a separate item for the President’s Task Force on classification and declassification (PRD-29). He indicated that Freeman would likely raise the matter of the Committee’s views on this at lunch. Anna Nelson stated that the Committee needs to know specifically how the task force was formed before it could offer useful comment. It was agreed that the Committee would meet briefly in executive session just before lunch to consider the materials in their briefing package on the PRD-29 Task Force.

Slany presented the Historian’s report. He stated that PA/HO is still publishing backlog volumes for the late 1950’s. The Office will publish 12-14 volumes in 1993. The schedule calls for PA/HO to publish 18 or more volumes next year in order to meet the legislative goal by 1996. The Office is on schedule.

He stated that PA is committing all the resources necessary to meet the requirements of the law. PA/HO is trying to keep costs down -- now ranging anywhere from $25 to $35 thousand per volume -- through editorial measures and less expensive arrangements with the GPO. He said that although the Office is trying to whittle down the size of the volumes, PA/HO historians try to maximize the amount of material within the smaller volumes.

Slany stated that 2 senior historians, Mabon and Noring, have recently retired or are about to retire and that PA/HO will probably lose a junior historian in the fall. David Humphrey will join the staff in July. Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs Tom Donilan and Freeman have authorized us to fill the Mabon and Noring vacancies. PA/HO will go as far afield as necessary in doing so, but Slany pointed out that filling vacancies from outside the Department was a protracted process at best. Humphrey’s security clearance had taken 8 months. Kimball observed that this could mean vacancies for as long as a year. He thought this was bound to have an impact on the work of the office. He noted that the Committee had previously expressed concern about the length of time required for clearance; he had written a letter to the Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security (DS) about the Humphrey clearance. For the record, the Committee expressed concern that vacancies in PA/HO be filled and security clearances be obtained expeditiously.

Slany stated that PA/HO is trying to deal with the problem of requirements for special handling and storage of highly classified documents, especially those of other agencies, which have to be kept in the PA/HO vault separate from other material being compiled. The Office is trying to arrange with DS and the other agencies for downgrading such documents or modification of the handling restrictions. George Herring stated that if this will have a long-term impact on the series, then the Committee should be concerned. Deputy Historian Glenn LaFantasie stated that DS had agreed to separating the TS documents and keeping the other material in barlocks within the PA/HO vault. Kimball asked if there wasn’t a long-term plan for new quarters. Slany replied that it was very long term. Kimball stated that PA/HO should let the Committee know immediately if it concluded the problem would have a long-term impact on the Foreign Relations schedule.

With regard to declassification, Slany said the Department’s declassification review, particularly for newly compiled volumes, is moving on schedule. The problem is to clear and publish the backlog of volumes compiled in the 80s, some of which were undergoing re-review by agencies. HDR and PA/HO have agreed that PA/HO will assume responsibility for declassification coordination of material outside the Department of State. Donilan has agreed to the establishment of a 4-person unit whose principal task will be to coordinate and monitor declassification by other agencies. Slany thought it should be possible -- with the implementation of new procedures such as simultaneous initial review by all agencies except the NSC within the first 120 days -- to complete the declassification of a volume within a year. Kimball asked whether these were new positions. Slany replied that some came from HDR, some from PA. PA/Ho will try to take over this
responsibility next month and fill the vacancies as soon as possible, probably using detailees from within and outside the Department in the interim. Chaddic stated that for administrative reasons, this was a good time for HDR to turn over this responsibility.
Arnold Taylor inquired about the status of the Congo volume. David Herschler stated that 64 documents were sent to the NSC in April.

Kimball pointed out that according to the status of volumes list, some documents had been at other agencies for many months and in some cases, over a year. There was some discussion of the problem of the Justice Department, which has had some documents for over a year. Jeanne Pryor stated that declassification authority at Justice was fragmented and there was no one with declassification authority in the Attorney General’s office, although the Department had now appointed a Deputy Attorney General who would have this authority. Slany stated that agencies need to have centralized declassification authority. Kimball suggested that PA/HO try to get an MOU on declassification with the Justice Department.

Noting some delays in the declassification schedule at the CIA, Kimball asked if the Department was giving the agency a little leeway in the hope of obtaining more favorable declassification action. Slany noted that CIA was facing the same hurdles as the Department in responding to the transition in declassification policy. He suggested that this matter be tabled until John Pereira joins the Committee on Friday morning.

Kimball then inquired if PA/HO had as yet worked out any MOU with the Defense Department. Slany said no. He had invited Brian Kinney to come to the Committee meeting, but Kinney thought he had nothing to say of interest to the Committee. Kimball said the Committee would take the next step and send some members to DOD to do some random sampling of documents, in accordance with the legislation. The Committee agreed to proceed with a request for such access.

Slany noted the Committee’s similar concerns expressed at previous meetings about the NSA. He pointed out that PA/HO had established a new contact at that agency, and asked the Committee to defer action regarding the NSA until the next meeting.

Slany pointed out that the early transfer of Department records to NARA impinges on PA/HO’s work in that records accessioned by NARA may be inaccessible for a while. David Langbart said that Department records at Suitland are accessible to PA/HO historians. Herschler said the Presidential Correspondence lot file which was recently sent to
Main Archives was inaccessible until PA/HO got them to do something. Kimball said PA/HO should bring this to the Committee’s attention if it becomes an insoluble problem. Slany said there may be a conflict between the goal of making records available to the public and publishing the series as fast as possible. Nelson said the series should take priority.

Slany raised the question of making the Committee records available to the public as required by law. There was general agreement that the records should be retired to NARA but some uncertainty as to when this should be done. Ann Van Camp proposed that the records should be transferred after two years. Herschler stated that PA/HO had a draft disposition schedule which was under consideration with the Department’s records managers. Kimball recommended that PA/HO work out a disposition schedule in accordance with the spirit of Van Camp’s proposal.
The Committee recessed for a break.

When the Committee reconvened, John Fawcett, Assistant Archivist for Presidential Libraries, discussed the decision by LBJ Library Director Harry Middleton to make available to the PA/HO staff and to the public the taped meetings and telephone conversations recorded during the Johnson Administration. This was a particularly noteworthy accomplishment, according to Fawcett, given that the statutory 50-year opening date has not been reached. Fawcett stressed that Middleton had asked the Department to assist in the declassification of transcripts of the recordings used for Foreign Relations research by PA/HO historians, and that Middleton could justify opening the materials in advance of the 50-year date on the basis of the Library and Department’s cooperative effort.

Nelson asked who reviews the tapes for privacy. Fawcett responded that the LBJ Library does, and that David Humphrey and Tina Houston of the LBJ Library staff were assigned the task of reviewing the tapes for privacy and national security concerns. Middleton himself intended to begin reviewing transcripts of telephone conversations in September.

Fawcett noted Humphrey’s imminent departure from the LBJ Library to join the PA/HO staff. Given the current staffing situation, he indicated there might be difficulties in filling the foreign policy vacancy at the Library, which could impact the process of opening the recordings and transcripts to the Department and the public. He informed the Committee of NARA’s recent requests, under the FY 94 budget, for additional staff to work at various Presidential libraries: 23 Bush, 6 JFK, and
13 positions to handle access issues associated with the Nixon materials. Fawcett said that unfortunately these requests were not approved, and were cut to 9, 0 and 0, respectively. NARA staff levels, he added, were currently at the level expected of it in three years under the Clinton Administration’s mandate to reduce government personnel. He said that such a pared-down staff will adversely affect the rate at which NARA will process and open documents.

Bradford Perkins asked how many people were assigned to work on acess and declassification of foreign policy materials at the Presidential libraries. Fawcett indicated there were 3 at the JFK Library and 3 (plus 1 State-supported detailee) at the LBJ Library. Perkins then asked about the possibility of moving existing staff from one library to another, such as from the FDR library to work on the Foreign Relations project. Fawcett responded that NARA does not move permament staff from one library to another since it costs approximately $100,000 to move one staff person.

Fawcett stressed that Presidential records beginning with the Reagan administration are subject to the Freedom of Information Act five years after being deposited at the Presidential library. This means that the Reagan materials will be subject to the FOIA next January, and NARA anticipated a heavy number of requests.

Kimball expressed concern about NARA’s staffing problems and how they would impact on Foreign Relations. Fawcett responded that the Nixon materials pose the biggest problem because of the very large volume of material, the cuts in NARA’s staff, and the peculiar access agreement guiding the Nixon papers. Fawcett informed the Committee that this access agreement allows Nixon himself to grant or reject access to his papers.

Betty Glad returned to the topic of the Johnson telephone tapes. She asked what the law was concerning the rights of individuals who were taped without their permission. Fawcett responded by saying that as long as one individual consents to taping the conversation the other individual in effect reliquishes his or her right to censor the tape.

Fawcett reminded the Committee that these recordings include conversations with individuals who are currently in Congress, and that other recorded individuals are still alive. Thus, the issue of privacy was a crucial one, especially because these recordings will be available before the 50-year release date. Perkins asked if NARA was breaking the law by making these tapes available. Fawcett said it was not so much the case of a barrier, but intrepretation of Middleton’s authority to release of these recordings.

Kimball again asked what the Committee could do to help, especially with access to the Nixon materials. Fawcett said that NARA’s relations with Nixon had become adversarial, in that Nixon’s attorneys are suing the Archives over the agency’s decision to allow FOIA requests for access to the finding aids to Nixon materials. He anticipated that Nixon would be a tough negotiator who would demand a quid pro quo. This might make access by PA/HO to the Nixon materials more difficult.

Returning to the question of the Johnson recordings, Nelson asked, considering PA/HO’s time limitations, whether it was a good expenditure of PA/HO staff time to listen to these tapes. LaFantasie said that these tapes could be particularly useful as a source to turn to when gaps that could not otherwise be filled appear in the record.

Kimball reiterated his concern with NARA’s staff problems and asked again if there was something the Committee could do. Fawcett replied that he thought it would be helpful for the Committee to maintain a continuing interest in NARA staff levels, but that even if it had received the 13 requested positions, such staff would not help the Foreign Relations series immediately because these people would require clearances and training, and that would take time.

Kimball asked what the best plan should be for the Committee to respond to this problem. He offered to write a letter, a memorandum, or wait to mention this in the Committee’s annual report. Van Camp said a decision needed to be made now about what the Committee should do. She supported the idea of writing a letter to an appropriate official, and stated that the Committee represented a large enough constituency to add credibility to such a letter. Kimball suggested addressing the letter to Secretary of State Christopher and to the appropriate official at NARA. Fawcett reminded Kimball that even when NARA had used the language of the Foreign Relations statute to argue for additional positions, these positions were not granted.

Nancy Smith of the Office of Presidential Libraries referred to a meeting attended by Harry Middleton, Slany and Herschler, at which Middleton expressed the hope that State would declassify entire transcripts of taped Johnson telephone conversations, and not only those extracts that State intended to use in its Foreign Relations volumes. Smith also reminded the Committee that the Department should think hard about identifying specific conversations in the Nixon tapes now, given its huge volume, in order to plan effectively for the next round of research. She informed everyone that Nixon’s diary is open, but that access to the log of recorded conversations is subject to negotiation with Nixon’s attorney and to FOIA requests.

Kimball proposed to write a letter on behalf of the Committee to Secretary Christopher, with a copy to an appropriate official at NARA, in which concern over NARA’s staffing problems and potential access problems for PA/HO research in the Nixon materials would be highlighted.

Kenneth McDonald, Chief Historianr of the CIA, briefed the Committee on collection of documentation on Iran and Guatemala. He said that work on Guatemala documentation was going well, in fact all the material had been identified. A member of his staff was preparing a history on Guatemala based on the documentation, and the agency was undertaking systematic review of the documents on Guatemala for 1954. His office was still working on identification and collection of the documenation on Iran.

McDonald then reported that the CIA’s Center for the Study of Intelligence has planned conferences on: 1) Teaching Intelligence, October 1-2, 1993; 2) Harry Truman and the Origins of the CIA, (cosponsored with the Truman Library), March 17-18, 1994; and 3) Soviet Strategic Estimates, October 1994. The History Staff will publish documents on CIA’s origins for the Truman conference and a collection of declassified estimates on Soviet capabilities for the third symposium. He noted that the Historical Review Group plans to review for declassification all estimates on the former Soviet Union 10 years old and older, and that CIA had already relesased portions of the 1976 “A-Team, B-Team” estimates.

Kimball expressed concern with the possibility of a duplication of effort if both State and the CIA publish histories on the foreign policy of the U.S. He emphasized that there needs to be good communication, a liaison, between State and the CIA. McDonald said that the CIA does not want to duplicate the efforts of State, and is not trying to compete with Foreign Relations. He added that his office had worked closely with Tom Thorne on providing PA/HO with documents from the Truman era.

Kimball asked whether Thorne’s effort provided an opportunity to publish in Foreign Relations documents that were previously denied declassification during the years 1945-1950. Emily Rosenberg noted that prefaces to the volumes mention the possibility of later publication of documentation from the CIA. She asked if McDonald’s staff had a plan to publish such documentation. McDonald responded that the CIA Historical Staff is not currently working to publish documentation originally denied from Foreign Relations volumes, but that they could help arrange for declassification review if State provided them with a list of documents previously denied.

Bradford Perkins asked who at CIA is responsible for declassification policy. In reply, McDonald emphasized that the CIA History Staff has no role at all in declassification matters, which are the responsibility of John Pereira’s Historial Review Group. The History Staff’s research program and publications, he added, are reviewed by the CIA History Advisory Board, a body of about a dozen senior Agency officers from all directorates.

LaFantasie then gave his report. He said that the LBJ research plan has gone forward with 8 research trips to the Library since last September. Some of the research had been undertaken in a team approach which seemed to be particularly effective. He informed the Committee of a new management tool that was recently introduced to the PA/HO staff, outlining its provisions for periodic reviews throughout the manuscript process to assess document selection, annotation and other areas of preparation, and containing 10 milestones to monitor whether the volume was meeting the schedule.

Perkins asked how long it takes to complete a manuscript. LaFantasie said about a year. Perkins asked LaFantasie to explain to him what a milestone was. LaFantasie said, for example, halfway into the manuscript process, the division chief, editor, and compiler would meet to discuss the status of the manuscript.

Perkins remarked that he thought meeting ten times a year corresponding to the 10 milestones seemed like it would be a lot of review in one year. LaFantasie said that it was simply a management tool, and that its development was prompted in part by a suggestion made by Emily Rosenberg at the last Advisory Committee meeting.

Rosenberg pointed out that she had not intended to suggest introducing a new management tool, but to develop a means by which the Committee’s concerns over the shortened manuscript page length could be addressed so that the targeted page length for particular volumes could be shortened or lengthened depending on the subject matter, and to ensure that a dynamic process exists while the PA/HO staff prepares the manuscript. She said that she did not want her earlier suggestion to be interpreted as a signal to increase PA/HO’s quantity of paperwork.

LaFantasie offered to let the Committee look at the first Johnson compilation, Arms Control, Vol. XI, 1964-1968, before the next Advisory Committee meeting, but warned that it is not complete. He added that the management tool would facilitate his answering questions from the Committee about the status of certain manuscripts.

Kimball asserted that the Committee needed to define its role in assessing the Johnson volumes. He stated that Anna Nelson and Arnold Taylor should look at the Arms Control volume in advance of the next Advisory Committee meeting.
The Committee recessed at 11:45 into a brief executive session, followed by lunch.

Bennett Freeman, Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Public Affairs Bureau, joined the Advisory Committee toward the end of lunch. He welcomed the Committee and said that the Department was grateful for all its fine efforts. Freeman explained that Tom Donilon, the new PA Assistant Secretary, and Mike McCurry, the Senior Deputy Assistant Secretary, were committed to supporting the work of the Historian’s Office and making sure that the Foreign Relations statute was fully implemented.

Freeman said that personally he took an interest in the Historian’s Office because of his own background as a student of history. Having only recently arrived at the Department, however, he could not claim to have a command of all the issues that are involved in the publication of the Foreign Relations series and the systematic declassification of the State Department’s 30-year-old records. Most of his time, he said, has been taken up with writing speeches and building a new speech-writing unit within the PA Bureau. He said that in the coming weeks he expects to familiarize himself with the key issues facing the Committee and that he will rely on Kimball’s and Slany’s guidance in gaining a better understanding of the work that needs to be done.

In response to a question about the PA Bureau’s role in dealing with the Presidential Directive on revising the Executive Order on Classification and Declassification, Freeman said that he would have to study the directive more closely, but he could tell the Committee that the PA Bureau leadership, and Donilan in particular, felt that too much responsibility had been placed in the hand’s of the Department’s security personnel. He said that the PA Bureau would look into the possibility of correcting that situation.
Freeman then excused himself, saying that he hoped to meet with the Committee again before its meeting was over, and extended best wishes to the Committee for a productive meeting.

Kimball announced that the Advisory Committee had decided during lunch that a subcommittee consisting of Nelson and Taylor would look at the Arms Control volume for the Johnson Administration. He then called upon Frank Machak, Director of the Department’s Office of Privacy, Freedom of Information, and Declassification Review (FPC).

Machak commented on the Working Group report on opening the Department’s 30-year old and older records, which he called a step forward. He said that the report makes clear that the Department takes the legislation seriously. Machak added that from his perspective, as one who would have to be an implementer, the report was a very good first product, although it was not perfect; the report did have “soft spots,” and there continued to be disagreements on interpretation of language. He repeated, however, that this was a good first step, and noted that the report would also make others who had not been involved in the process more comfortable with these issues.

Michael Kurtz, Acting Assistant Archivist for the Office of the National Archives, said that the data distributed to the Committee concerning the status of declassification for the 1960-63 records showed that they had a long way to go, adding that they were encountering resource and guideline problems which explained this. Kurtz distributed a list of Department guidelines already in NARA’s possession, and a list of guidelines for which NARA was waiting. He noted that the National Archives had made a commitment to providing at least three staff members for the project in addition to the six that would be funded by the Department of State. Kurtz said that only three of those nine had been cleared thus far, but pointed out that the Department of State does not pay for these employees until they are cleared and on board.

In response to a question by Kimball, Kurtz assured the Committee that archival processing did not stand in the way of declassification. He said that the Working Group had had a difficult series of discussions, but had attempted to set milestones, which was essential from a management and public perception point of view. They would have to do more work on how the process would work and the operational details would have to be worked out, particularly concerning the issue of other agency information, but the Working Group report provided a framework for this. Kurtz added that the Presidential Task Force offered hope for a broader level of declassification reform.

Kimball emphasized that he wanted the Advisory Committee to understand the context of the report. He noted that monitoring and aiding the declassification process would be a very challenging issue for the Advisory Committee and asked if the Committee had any questions or comments about the report.

Brad Perkins said that he thought there was supposed to be a “drop-dead date” after which documentation would automatically be declassified. Kimball said that the target date was January 1, 1997 for release of material through 1966. Perkins said they needed to establish a “drop-dead date” so that the records would be opened by that date even if the deadline for review was not met.

At this point, the Committee interrupted its deliberations to welcome Deputy Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs and Deputy Spokesman Richard Boucher. Boucher greeted the Committee and assured it that the Department had a commitment to meeting the Congressional deadline. He noted that the Working Group had come up with some practical ideas. Boucher said that the new team in PA had been briefed on the Working Group report and had a commitment to the process and everyone wanted to come up with practical, workable solutions. He added, however, that there were still bureaucratic hoops to go through.

When discussion of the Working Group report resumed, Perkins noted that the report, while offering promise, was really nothing more than a “pious hope” that the 30 year release line could be achieved. He argued that they had to have a “drop-dead date” to make people do what they were supposed to do. Kimball pointed out that the report was in its final form, but added that the Advisory Committee could and should add its comments. Slany concurred in this.

Emily Rosenberg said that she had understood that the Committee had previously endorsed a “drop-dead date” and asked what had happened to this in the Working Group discussions. Machak offered his personal opinion concerning a “drop dead date” that he had been in the Department of State for a long time and he could tell the Committee that “it ain’t going to happen in this building.” The Committee might consider him a hardliner, but to many working in the declassification field he was considered a liberal. No one in the Department was going to say, “Open 9000 feet of records on January 1, 1997.” The notion of automatic declassification was both impractical and illegal under the current regulations. There was no way that documents were going to be released without some analysis and recommendations to the Secretary of State.

Perkins pointed out that the Department would have four years to find out what could not be released. Machak replied that the Working Group had tried to put checkpoints in the report, calling for early analyses and mandatory reporting. This provided a framework which would help them to keep their eyes on the ball. Machak emphasized again that a “drop-dead date” scares people, but said that he agreed that they had to have targets and checkpoints.

Slany pointed out that the Advisory Committee had been given the power to monitor this process and that it would know whether or not it was working. Kurtz said that the National Archives had considered favorably a “drop-dead date” for certain categories of records along with the notion of anlyzing the files more important to researchers first, but pointed out that these are Department of State records. The Working Group had established the principle of setting priorities. Kurtz added that they also had to be concerned with other agencies’ equities.

Kimball commented that he shared the doubts that the January 1, 1997 deadline could be met and argued that this showed the importance of setting priorities, since the deadline would likely not be met for all of the records. Rosenberg suggested that the Advisory Committee should say that it would call for a “drop-dead date” for the lowest risk categories if it appeared that the deadline would not be met.

Van Camp asked Machak to discuss two aspects of the report -- setting priorities and risk analysis. Perkins suggested that they could do risk analysis by sampling documents. Machak replied that they would indeed have to sample documents, as the volume of documentation precluded page-by-page review of all categories of records, and there could no longer be a three-tiered review, as is currently the case. He warned, however, that they might discover that sampling would not provide the answers the Committee wanted. He hoped that their first experience with sampling during the early stage of analysis called for in the report would be helpful. Kimball noted that the new law defines exempted categories in different terms than the Executive Order with regard to information which “might reasonably damage” current foreign relations.

Taylor asked Machak about personnel. Who would be the “qualified experts” who would be part of the risk assessment analyses called for in item #4 and the declassification center called for in item #7? Would these people play a significant role in determining what was declassified or merely an advisory one? Machak replied that they were meant to play a significant role, but until teams were organized and sampling was under way, it was hard to speculate on the roles of specific individuals. Taylor said that he was worried that the process would be dominated by people with a bias for classification. Machak stated that he did not buy the idea that there had been a bias against declassification in the past, but he felt that the new teams would not have it in any case.

Kimball suggested rephrasing Taylor’s question: will others who had appropriate training besides retired Foreign Service Officers be used? Machak pointed out that it would be teams who would make the decisions rather than any single individual, although eventually one single person would have to sign off. Kimball said that the Advisory Committee was interested in bringing different people with a different approach into the declassification process, but wondered whether they would have equal stature.

Machak pointed out that such people would have to have Top Secret clearances, which limited the universe they could choose from. He anticipated that some mix of Foreign Service Officers, Civil NARA employees, and Foreign and Civil Service annuitants would be in the pool. The Foreign Service annuitants were a viable resource. Machak emphasized that the Department has to use experts for declassification (i.e., former consular officers for consular files), who have delegated authority from the bureaus. A bureau such as EUR would not be prepared to authorize PhD historians to declassify its records.

Nelson commented that the Advisory Committee’s role in this process would probably be carried out by one person. Therefore, she wondered what would happen and whether it would matter if the Advisory Committee member said, “I disagree,” especially concerning national security issues. Would the results justify the Advisory Committee’s optimism? Slany noted that the Office of the Historian’s experience had been that while the Advisory Committee’s views perhaps were too advanced to be fully accepted, the Department had already been moving in that direction. Kimball suggested that the Working Group’s emphasis on results in its recommendations was indicative of this. Nelson reiterated her skepticism.

Van Camp commented on the positive elements in the Working Group report, which were much more than she expected, but asked what was different about its proposal concerning the Department of State’s responsibility under the new plan. She was concerned that the new plan should offer real change and not be merely a faster version of the old one; she also questioned NARA’s role in the new system.

Machak replied that he was not sure what would emerge. There had to be agreement on what documents were involved. He said that the Department of State did not intend to cut out the National Archives and saw it in a complementary role, although he was still not sure how this would work. Machak suggested that perhaps the Department would do the Decimal files and NARA the Post and Lot files. He noted that Joe Chaddic thought there were “efficiencies” here.

Kimball commented that the Working Group plan took some pressure off of Chaddic because he did not have to have immediate guidelines. Still, guidelines for already accessioned records -- some 3500 cubic feet -- would have do be done. Smith pointed out that the guidelines were important to the Presidential libraries.

Chaddic noted that there would still be guidelines. He added that there were various efficiencies in the Working Group report and that better cooperation within the building and the synergy of a team effort rather than using one or two senior reviewers at NARA would also help them to meet the deadlines. Other agency officials could be invited to participate in the review. Chaddic warned, however, that the projected completion date of January 1, 1997 was based on starting the new process by April 1, 1993. There was already nearly a two-month delay. Kurtz asked Chaddic when the guidelines would be ready, to which he replied by the end of the current fiscal year.

Perkins commented that they were evidently trying to speed up the declassification process, but not to change the standards. He noted that he remained sceptical about not having a “drop-dead date” and asked Chaddic how much sampling and risk assessment did he contemplate? Chaddic replied that he could not answer that now.

Kimball raised the question of other agency equity. Should they get other agencies involved in the process at an earlier stage? He thought that the idea should be to place the burden for speedy review on the agency with the equity, but feared this might be too confrontational. Chaddic replied that he was hoping for help from the Advisory Committee on this. The Department of State would consult other agencies or notify them that they had equity. If there was no response, the Department could say that the documents were going to the National Archives and would be open within six months. He added that he expected this to raise legal issues that would have to be resolved at the time.

Kimball suggested that Chaddic was talking about a “drop dead” date for other agency equity. Slany noted that this was why the language in the Working Group report had been carefully chosen to ensure that other agency material “would not be permitted to delay the transfer and opening of Department of State records.”

Machak said that they had been having discussions with other agencies to alert them to what was on the horizon in the Department of State. These discussions had indicated that many agencies were down-sizing their declassification staffs. The intention was to inform the leadership in these agencies that there was going to be a demand and that they needed to be prepared. Because of clearance problems, interagency representatives needed to have authority and not just take back
copies of documents to be vetted internally. He thought there might be a role for colonels and two-star generals in this team approach. Machak reminded the Committee that cooperation was easier and more effective than confrontation.

Glad asked if other agencies, such as the CIA, would agree to sampling? Machak responded that he hoped to involve them in the process. Kurtz commented that the National Archives was very concerned with referring documents to other agencies. This was the bane of its existence.

Kimball asked whether the Working Group’s proposal regarding other agency equity would apply to materials in the Presidential libraries. Herschler pointed out that these materials for the most part are not Department of State records, although many copies of Department records are contained in the files. Herring expected that the Department’s new declassification effort would have a ripple effect on the libraries. Kimball suggested that the declassification decisions made by the Department on particular documents should be conveyed to other agencies, particularly the Presidential libraries.

Machak noted that while there was not much enthusiasm for interagency working groups, they have in fact worked quite well in the past. He pointed out that the Advisory Committee had the ability to influence others in this regard. He said that the Department was working with the Presidential libraries on compatible software so it could provide the libraries with data on documentation the Department had declassified. This project was part of the Department of State’s five-year plan. Nelson pointed out that since most of the earlier Presidential libraries did not have computerized declassification systems, this project would only be helpful for documents much more recent than 30 years old.

Herschler stressed the importance of an interagency database for declassification decisions. The Interagency Security Oversight Office had been working on this question, but nothing had come of it thus far. Machak stated that when he had suggested a government-wide database of declassified documents at one of these meetings, he had met with considerable opposition. On the other hand, Machak continued, FPC and PA/HO had developed an electronic link between the Foreign Relations document list and the Department’s declassification database. Herschler indicated that printout lists of declassified Department documents could be provided to the Presidential libraries in the same way lists of declassified Foreign Relations documents now could be provided to the libraries.

Herring expressed his concern with the mindset of the declassifiers. He asked if there was any way that there could be re-education in order to bring the mindset of the declassifiers up to date along with the declassification process. Machak said that the Working Group had considered this and the idea was to motivate people to get the job done. He emphasized the importance of having a covering memo with the context and setting of the Secretary’s commitment to the process to get the principals to sign on to the plan. He noted that the Department’s new Assistant Secretary for Administration, Pat Kennedy, had already had two conversations with him about the Working Group and its report. He added that Kennedy expected to play a role in the Department’s response to the Presidential Directive on classification and declassification.

Betty Glad asked whether the Presidential Task Force on a new Executive Order would make the declassification task easier. Kurtz replied that he was on the Task Force and was chair of the Subcommittee on Declassification. He told the Advisory Committee that there would be two days of public testimony on June 9 and June 10 in the Great Hall of the Department of Justice. The Subcommittee on Declassification would welcome input from the Advisory Committee. Kurtz also noted that the Task Force was supposed to have a draft Executive Order by November 15, 1993.

Nelson asked Machak what would motivate change in the new Executive Order? Machak said that, from his personal perspective, the Working Group had been the most positive thing he had seen in more than 20 years. The internal conditioning process has begun in the Department. The Presidential Task Force was a forum for issues raised in the Department’s Working Group.

Rosenberg asked whether the Department intended to involve other agencies in risk assessment during the first 60-day period. Chaddic reiterated that the Committee should not start the clock on the 60-day period until the declassification Center was funded, space allocated, and people assigned. Rosenberg asked again if they would operate within an inter-agency framework, and Chaddic replied that there would be informal cooperation.
The Committee recessed for a break.

George Herring indicated that he would summarize the subcommittee reports, which covered declassification actions on four topics in five volumes. He noted that Perkins and Van Camp would supplement his remarks.

Herring said that some of the the documents on Tibet were discussed at the end of the last Advisory Committee meeting. The subcommittee heard from the desk officer, Gary Williams, and the HDR reviewer, Al Harding.

LaFantasie pointed out that there were six documents for the 1958-1960 China volume and two documents for the 1961-1963 China volume. After the Committee had expressed concern at the last meeting, LaFantasie revisited the documentation, instructed Harriet Schwar to collect additional documentation and secondary literature, and worked with the Eisenhower Library to obtain the additional materials. Out of the new sources collected, LaFantasie had selected five additional documents for inclusion in the 1958-1960 China volume. Publication of the volume was temporarily suspended and the volume would be remade with the Tibet documents (mostly for 1959) in a separate compilation. He added that PA/HO had met with the desk officer in advance of the subcommittee meeting.

Herring reported that the desk officer explained that certain documents on Tibet had been denied in whole or in part because it was felt that their official publication could lead to further repression in Tibet. This reasoning, Herring remarked, seemed “strained and tortured” to the subcommittee. Mr. Williams did agree, however, to re-review the previously compiled documents and review the newly compiled documents with an open mind. Herring noted that no decision of the Advisory Commitee was needed now. The subcommittee supported the PA/HO initiative on Tibet. He added that his conviction of the centrality of the Tibet documents was reinforced.

Perkins pointed out the difficulty in sorting out operational details from policy considerations in some of the documents in question. He reiterated the subcommittee’s view that the desk officer’s concern with political repercussions in Tibet from publication of the documentation was “strained and unimaginative.”

Rosenberg complimented LaFantasie for his decision to stop publication of the volume until the Tibet documentation issue could be resolved, and she complimented LaFantasie and Schwar for their effort to uncover additional documentation. She inquired whether the desk officer was better informed of the review appeals procedures than the desk officer her
subcommittee had met with the past winter. LaFantasie replied that it was clear to him that the desk officer had read the 1991 law. Herschler said that PA/HO had covered these points in their April meeting with the desk officer. Van Camp said the Tibet desk officer was cooperative, and Pereira later said that he would meet with the CIA officer on the same issue. Herschler confirmed that the Tibet documents will go to the CIA as well as the EAP Bureau.

Herring next reported on the Cuba, 1961-1963, volume. Here again the documents in question did not require a Committee decision. John Pereira, director of the CIA’s Historical Review Group, had reported that his office had recommended --after re-review of the 14 documents submitted by PA/HO --release of five documents in full and nine in part. Some deleted material was restored. The full texts of the documents would be available in two or three weeks.

Herring then discussed Indonesia, 1958-1960. The subcommittee had discussed this issue in November 1992. The documents involved CIA issues also. The deletions had removed evidence of covert operations in Indonesia, as well as other issues. The CIA conducted a re-review and agreed to release some of the earlier deletions. The record now shows that there were covert operations and one can read between the lines to fill in much of the remaining missing information. The PA/HO compiler, Edward Keefer, was satisfied that the volume was now much improved, and the subcommittee was prepared to go along with that view. The original documents did not contain much detail.

Perkins added that these matters should be mentioned in the preface to the volume. Herring noted that the subcommittee had reviewed a draft text of the preface and had made a recommendation that seemed agreeable at the subcommittee meeting, so the subcommittee recommended that PA/HO should move forward with publication of the volume.

Herring then turned to the question of the Israeli Dimona facility in the Near East volume for 1961-1962 that had been discussed at the February Committee meeting. Perkins reported that a long telegraphic report by the American Ambassador was denied, but a previously released document in the fiche collection covered much the same ground, and that has been moved to this print volume. Much of the remaining documentation was released by the NEA Bureau, including most portions of U.S. assessments of Israeli atomic capabilities.

Van Camp added that three issues were earlier studied and tagged as important by the subcommittee, and Nina Noring was confident that these issues were now adequately covered in the volume. Herschler had summarized the points in a memorandum to Chaddic following the previous Advisory Committee meeting.

Herring felt that the work of the subcommittees was very constructive in chipping away at the institutional mindset against declassification. He also thought that it chipped away at any PA/HO mindset not to bother appealing documents it may view as lost causes. The subcommittee in effect encourages PA/HO to try again. Van Camp concurred, adding that PA/HO has had success itself in getting specific documents released with Advisory Committee support. Herschler noted that PA/HO had received favorable results from several informal appeals, which had made it unnecessary to bring the matter to the Committee’s attention. LaFantasie thanked Jean Pryor and Joe Chaddic for their assistance in this process.

Kimball suggested that the Committee should talk about the Executive Order tomorrow morning. If members could come to the Department for their photographs at 8:30 a.m., they could begin discussion on the Executive Order at 9 a.m.

Rosenberg asked whether the Advisory Committee should take a position advocating the publication of documentation previously denied for inclusion in the Foreign Relations volumes dealing with the late 1950s. Could PA/HO catch up in these cases, as in Guatemala and Iran? Glad thought that PA/HO should try to catch up, referring to the release of the CIA Center’s narrative studies. Slany said he was reluctant to disrupt the current publication schedule.

Kimball asked whether the CIA should be encouraged to publish supplemental documentation to these volumes. He noted, however, that Ken McDonald had told the Committee earlier in the day that the CIA Historical Staff does not exist to supplement the Foreign Relations series.

Rosenberg said her understanding of McDonald’s remarks was that his staff was not involved in documentary editing but that he would listen to a PA/HO specific request for such supplemental assistance in this area. Glad noted that there were other areas that could be supplemented, e.g., the Hungarian revolution of 1956, which would be somewhat similar to Iran and Guatemala.

Slany remarked that the Committee could recommend a supplementary volume covering all these issues, as on the general relationship of the CIA to foreign policy prepared by Tom Thorne covering the years 1946-1950. Picker said that it could be pointed out in the prefaces that the omission of
intelligence matters would be remedied in a future volume if the Committee so agreed. Slany wondered how much of this record we have seen, and Kimball said it is not the Committee’s responsibility to worry about previously published volumes. He added that supplemental compilations on intelligence would not be necessary if CIA documents were retired to the National Archives.

David Langbart remarked that NARA is not receiving CIA materials. They have received two CIA histories, and George Chalou had noted that these materials were “largely junk.” Much of this same material is in the State Department files and has appeared in other volumes in the series. Nelson said that the CIA had pulled records. Much that was sent to NARA was not open.

Kimball suggested that Slany and LaFantasie study the issue and make recommendations. Perkins asked whether the Committee wanted to put another volume on PA/HO’s plate. Kimball replied that the Committee was just thinking about it and wanted suggestions on feasibility. He did not want to impose a big burden. Herring said they could talk tommorrow with Pereira and McDonald about this.

Kimball next turned to the issue of the prefaces to certain Foreign Relations volumes to be considered by the Advisory Committee. He noted that in language common to each preface it was stated that “selective access” had been obtained by the Historical Office to the records of several government agencies while researching these volumes. Later in each preface it is stated that the volume was “prepared in a manner completely consonant with the standards of the statute” governing the publication of the Foreign Relations series. If the first statement is true, Kimball said, the second must necessarily be false. The Advisory Committee agreed to take up the matter the following day.
The session adjourned at 4:25 p.m.

The session convened at 9:20 a.m. to discuss the prefaces in some soon to be published Foreign Relations volumes. Kimball expressed his concern over inflated claims in the prefaces that the volumes were prepared “in a manner completely consonant with the standards and mandates of the statute.” He felt this is misleading to readers especially when the preface also states that the editors only had selective access. He had had comments from historians about the preface in the 1964 Vietnam volume, which claims that the editors were “confident” that they had complete access to all records. The recent discovery of the McCone files illustrates how dangerous such a statement can be. He thought that, in the long run, such a statement was misleading to scholars.

Slany pointed out that the editors looked at everything that was available to then at the time of compilation. Kimball still took issue with inflated claims about access to all records and suggested using the phrase: “the editor had access to all records located or known as of (date).” There was discussion about which date to use -- the date of compilation or the date of publication.
Perkins asked why the Committee’s boilerplate was not included in these prefaces.

Kimball reminded him that compilation of these volumes preceded the date of the 1991 statute, and the Committee had decided at one of its previous meetings not to include the boilerplate language in those prefaces.

Perkins then asked why the nature of the material deleted was not spelled out, especially when the percentage was as large as 8 percent, as in the Western Europe volumes. Charles Sampson, compiler of those volumes, explained that there was no one topic that was extensively deleted; the excisions covered many subjects in several compilations. Perkins reiterated that the reader should be told what kind of subjects have been deleted and mentioned that the language in the 1958-60 volume XII preface was a good model.

Nelson commented that since this volume (West Europe) was compiled in 1981, the preface did not even have to mention the 1991 law. Both Slany and LaFantasie felt strongly that it was essential to account for the law. Nelson felt that the prefaces for those volumes should ignore the fact that the law exists. LaFantasie pointed out that the public expectation is that the Department would respond to the law. Otherwise, readers would wonder what had happened to the law.
Glad agreed.

Kimball noted that the PA/HO staff did as much as possible, but that declassification problems created limitations. The volumes were compiled in the spirit of the law and he did not want to cast aspersions on the PA/HO staff.
Kimball returned to the concept of inflated claims of access. Rosenberg and Nelson pointed out that the phrase “range of sources” is also misleading.

Rosenberg asked about the publication status of these volumes. Rita Baker, technical editor, informed her that the two West Europe volumes were too far along to stop, but the other prefaces could be changed.

Nelson thought it was essential to get the phrase “range of sources” out. Rosenberg noted there were now two things significant to change: that phrase and the term “consonant.” Kimball pointed out that these changes could not happen in volume VII but the others could be changed.

Glad resurrected the issue of including in the prefaces a statement about the role of the Committee, such as “The compilation of this volume was completed before the Advisory Committee existed.” Kimball reminded her that the Committee had discussed that in previous meetings and had decided not include such a statement. Glad thought it was important to explain about Committee involvement, but Kimball said that no acceptable language had been found for these pre-Committee volumes. The Committee will not be involved.

Nelson separated the prefaces into three groups: those that cannot be changed (i.e., volume VII); those that could still be changed; and those that included the Committee boilerplate. Picker said she was confused by the language “originally compiled.” Sampson noted that a large percentage (20 percent) of the volume was originally denied; after the Berlin situation was clarified, the volume was re-reviewed and documentation was restored.
Kimball said he believed that PA/HO understood the Committee’s concerns and summarized the changes they required in the prefaces:

item.p: 2) use less categorical statements about access;
3) characterize the excisions, especially when the amount of deletions are significant, so that readers can be reassured there is no smoking gun.

div.p: Slany then asked the Committee members if they had any comments on the preface to the 1961-1963 volume on Berlin. The main difficulty had been how to describe the historians’ access to CIA files.

Herring commented that obviously it should be done very carefully. Kimball said that the preface should make clear that access was selective and did not mean full access to the files. LaFantasie pointed out that some researchers can ask for specific documents in specific files based on their previous experience with CIA records. Keefer noted that access to CIA records was better at the Presidential libraries than at the CIA.
Rosenberg requested some specific changes to the language about CIA access to emphasize that the historians had access to particular files, but not to all records at the CIA.

Nelson asked “if you ask for the Director’s files, what do you get?” Sampson said that everything is the Director’s files. There was a brief discussion about the provenance or lack of provenance of CIA documents.

Kimball wanted to include a statement in the preface indicating that the historians were allowed to see only what the CIA gives them. They agreed to the language: “The Department of State historians have been provided access to selective documentation of the CIA.” Kimball also wanted to include a statement that the historians were not allowed to publish complete file citations for the CIA documents.

Taylor (later in the discussion) asked why it was necessary to note in the preface what was excluded. If so, then there should be an explanation of why. The Committee agreed. Sampson explained that there was an overwhelming amount of very high-level documentation for this particular volume (1958-1960, VIII) and the selection of documents came from that body. Taylor asked that that explanation be included in the preface.

Kimball introduced the next item on the agenda: INR records. PA/HO historians had not previously been provided with access to INR files except those few that have been retired to NARA. Langbart confirmed that there were very few INR files in NARA except those in Lot 58 D 776 for the 1940s and 50s.

Jon Gibney, Deputy Director of the Office of Intelligence Liaison (INR/IL), introduced himself. He began by saying that there had never been a consistent or systematic review and retirement of INR records, but because of an OIG recommendation, INR was now working with the Department’s Records Management staff to set up a disposition schedule. In a few months to a year, INR will have completed this process of retiring files to preserve the historical record.

INR has a large body of unique records, of which his office is custodian. Although most of INR is an analytical bureau, his office is operational and is responsible for liaison with other intelligence agencies. The INR files contain documents dealing with various sensitive CIA, NSA, and DOD intelligence programs, sensitive law enforcement issues, and the record copy of all Roger Channel traffic; some of which date back to the 1950s. In some instances these files constitute a unique record of intelligence activity and may never be declassified. They mostly document other agency programs, and at least 1/3 are NSC or CIA documents, but there are many INR documents that present the Secretary with a framework for policy decisions.

He noted that it was difficult to understand the Reagan administration foreign policy without understanding covert operations. Covert operations are set up to be denied in perpetuity. Clandestine operations can be revealed by the U.S. Government for its own reasons.
Many of these records will now be retired, although they may not be declassified. He then asked for questions.

Without hesitation, Kimball asked about access by the historians to these files. Gibney said there was none. Perkins pointed out and Gibney agreed that the historians should have access to analytical files. Perkins said that access was one issue, declassification was another; the PA/HO historians should have access.
Kimball then read portions of the 1991 statute that guaranteed full access to historians to examine and select documents. Can that access to all INR documentation be granted?
Gibney said they were willing to look at the issue and agreed in theory, but most of the documents concerned other agency programs and any access must have permission of the agency involved.

Nelson asked if even the historical files (30 years or older) are so sensitive. Gibney said yes. Nelson then asked if any analytical or policy files could be declassified. Gibney said INR does not write policy memos, only analyses condensed from all intelligence sources. The historians would be hard put to find any connection between INR input and policy decisions.

Keefer pointed out that INR memos for the Secretary are available in the Secretary’s files. Gibney reminded the Committee that an intelligence product does not necessarily guide or influence policy. In his view the most interesting INR products are memoranda for the Secretary that devise a framework for the Secretary’s decisions, or explain the impact of intelligence.

Kimball said there are two problems: access for PA/HO historians and the transfer of material to NARA. He wondered if INR has any finding aids or how usable the records are. Could representatives from PA/HO and the Committee look at the records in order to provide the Secretary with advice about this records management problem? Gibney made a note.
Glad asked if INR had any internal histories. Gibney said no, his office only has files that officers can use.

Patterson noted that PA/HO has received a list of NIEs and SNIEs for the 1950s and asked if there is one for intelligence estimates and INR numbered research memoranda for the 1960s. Gibney made a note.

Kimball again reminded Gibney that PA/HO should have full access rather than having to ask for specific items. Gibney asked what dates of records PA/HO would need to see. Kimball noted that PA/HO needs to see records at least 25 years after the events. In response to a question from Rosenberg, Gibney said the records go back to the end of World War II.

Schwar asked if INR has files of restricted distribution telegrams from overseas to State on intelligence information. Gibney noted that his office has such records. He explained other ways that intelligence messages were transmitted to Washington.

Van Camp asked what happens to records that are retired but cannot be declassified. Gibney assured her that they are preserved and protected. Van Camp asked if the Committee can help to designate these records as permanent. Langbart interjected that INR was working with State’s Records Management staff and that there was as yet no disposition schedule authorizing retirement. Gibney noted that INR was reluctant to give up custody of the records at all.

Kimball agreed with Van Camp that the Committee should emphasize the desirability of maintaining the archival integrity of records retired by INR. Kimball pointed out that if PA/HO has full access, the process of declassification of these records is initiated.

It was later decided to include in the Committee’s report the following language: “the Committee appreciates Mr. Gibney’s informative comments, is pleased to acknowledge that INR is making an effort to identify and preserve its valuable records and hopes that INR will provide access to PA/HO historians to INR records.”
The Committee recessed for a break.

Kimball reconvened the meeting at 10:55 a.m. He announced that Van Camp would be the Committee’s representative for access to the records of the Bureau of Intelligence and Research (INR), and that Picker would deal with the records of the Office of the Legal Adviser (L). The Advisory Committee’s next report would stress the question of archival integrity.

John Pereira, Chief of the Historical Review Group (HRG) at the CIA, reported on declassification of CIA historical documentation. He began by observing that the CIA had established an Historical Review Group last year to handle declassification. New agency guidelines now presumed that documents would be reviewed for release at the 30-year mark; Strategic Estimates for the Soviet Union that were at least 10 years old would also be reviewed for release.

Pereira said that the CIA was trying to cooperate with State on declassification of documentation for Foreign Relations. One person in his office makes the declassification determination and refers documents to the directorates for concurrence in the decision. “Bookkeeping” delays during the transmission of documents had been reduced to 3-4 days from State to HRG, and to about a week from CIA back to State. The FOIA workload is heavy and has contributed to delays in transmitting completed work on Foreign Relations back to State.
The new guidelines were gradually changing the Agency mindset; for the most part only essentials like names of agents and operational details would remain protected.

The HRG would release the Job and Box Numbers of documents, although Pereira said that people who processed FOI requests foresaw an increased workload how that requestors would know what files to request. LaFantasie said that in the absence of more specific identifying information on the provenance of CIA documents, Foreign Relations might need to include Job and Box Numbers in the source notes. Perkins then wondered whether an increase in FOIA requests was a legitimate Agency concern; Kimball added that they could easily print more form letters reading “You’re in the queue.” Pereira replied that here was one more incentive to transfer documents to NARA, especially since his office must take custody of CIA records under its review, and therefore is responsible for handling FOIA requests for such records.

Nelson then asked when the JFK files would be open. Pereira replied that the President had not yet appointed a review board, and that many documents would not be transferred to NARA until the review board had had its say.

Patterson asked about release of NIEs for the Soviet Union. Pereira replied that all strategic estimates (not necessarily the raw data) and all political and economic estimates that were over 10 years old would be released after review by the intelligence community.

Perkins asked whether all 20-odd agencies involved in the declassification review process for the estimates would have to agree to release the NIEs. Pereira replied that the presumption now favored release.

Nelson asked about the progress of declassification. Pereira replied that once the JFK project was completed, Guatemala and Iran would be next. Later topics would include the Bay of Pigs and the Cuban Missile Crisis. He reiterated that progress could be slowed because although his staff takes possession of files, they must coordinate with components that respond to FOIA requests.

Kimball wondered whether “PR-related studies” affected support for PA/HO, and said that he would like to see the new Director commit himself to giving priority to support for Foreign Relations. He feared that Congress might divert CIA declassification efforts to more politically popular topics. Pereira said that special studies did divert personnel and resources from Foreign Relations. Gates had tried to emphasize declassification of areas of special interest rather than systematic release of records. It was hoped that Woolsey would make a specific declaration, or at least a general statement in favor of “openness.” He anticipated that once his staff had completed work on the JFK documentation, in August, more resources could be assigned to Foreign Relations.

Betty Glad asked about finding aids at the CIA. Pereira replied that they had only been developed so far for the JFK records. He would work with Kenneth McDonald to devise some. In reply to a question from Herschler, Pereira said that these finding aids might not necessarily meet PA/HO’s needs.

Slany explained that the State Department is required by law to open all records over 30 years old by October. A working group was devising a plan of action, but he still wondered whether the process could be expedited for documents originating in other agencies, in particular the CIA. Pereira said that release might be done by topics. When the JFK files were being reviewed, the CIA sent people to other agencies to expedite the process.

Nelson inquired whether Pereira’s office was involved in the Presidential Task Force on Declassification. Pereira replied that the CIA member on the Task Force is the agency’s director of security. Pereira added that he hoped to insert his staff’s perspective in the process in some way.

Betty Glad asked about levels of classification of CIA documents. Pereira replied that levels were subject to review, and that records disposition followed NARA schedules. There was no classification in perpetuity.

Kimball inquired when the internal debate over declassification at the CIA would be resolved. Pereira suggested that the internal debate was tied to determination of the CIA’s budget. The Historical Review Group, at least,
had gotten more funding and personnel. HRG had a staff of 20, 14 of whom worked full-time on the JFK request. Perkins asked if the staff would lose positions once the JFK project had concluded. Pereira said that he hoped it would not.

Keefer asked about finding aids, including a central file of incoming and outgoing cables. Pereira explained the files were set up for operational support, not for research. The operational files, including reports of agents, were organized not by subject, but by operational names.

Van Camp asked whether reassembling documents by topic might, by creating new files, cause problems for future researchers. Pereira said that there had been proposals to hire an archivist and a records manager to organize a broad range of CIA files.
Nelson wondered whether an organizational directory or administrative history, if available, would aid researchers. Pereira said that offices frequently changed their names.

Picker asked whether operational records would be put into electronic form. Pereira replied that only 10-12 year-old records had been digitized, and State was interested in 30-year-old records. Picker asked if it would be possible to scan the older records. Herschler cited the cost, time, and accuracy factors in scanning older documentation, and LaFantasie observed that the older documents often included handwritten notes.

Herring noted the agency’s resistance to retiring historical records to the National Archives, and inquired whether this mindset was changing. Pereira indicated that there had been selective change. Day-to-day operations remain very compartmentalized. The BNL investigation has ensouraged the agency to examine how its records are maintained.

Kimball finally asked how the Committee could accelerate the declassification process for Foreign Relations. Pereira replied that a statement about the value of the material to the published historical record would be helpful, especially in informing the CIA leadership.

Pereira left the meeting at 11:45. The Committee then discussed how to phrase a statement about the importance of CIA documents to the Foreign Relations series and foreign policy history, and on the importance of archival considerations for CIA documenation. Kimball asked Herring to draft the letter to the Director of Central Intelligence.
The committee recessed at noon for lunch.
Kimball asked for comments from the Historical Office staff on any subject pertaining to the Foreign Relations series or the work of the Committee.

Sampson noted that it was difficult for the staff Historians to find documents recording high-level Presidential meetings during the Johnson Administration before the Tom Johnson notes beginning in late 1967. He had found this to be the case in the Greece-Cyprus volume. LBJ disliked leaks on foreign policy matters so notes and records apparently are scarce.

Kimball asked if the newly available LBJ telephone and meetings transcripts would help. Herschler pointed out that recordings of Cabinet Room meetings only exist for 1968. Keefer noted that the CIA’s McCone Papers might be useful in filling in the gaps in certain instances. Kimball said the problem was duly noted and added that some reference to this problem might have to be added to the prefaces of the Johnson period volumes.

Sampson said the Department of State’s telegraphic records decline over the Johnson Administration with the backup microfilm reels missing telegrams by the dozens for 1967-1968. The use of nonspecific references to “Septels” within telegrams (referring to a “separate telegram” rather than citing the telegram’s full number) often caused insuperable annotation problems. Keefer said that distribution limitations such as NODIS and EXDIS raised difficulties in getting records into files. Recordkeepers have tried to refile these into the Central File but have not always been successful. Kimball asked if this applied to current records. Keefer said that it was less of a problem with telegrams kept electronically since 1973.

Patterson said that it would appear that the staff historians were not doing their jobs completely when they could not locate so many SEPTEL references. Nelson stated that the search for these reftels would prolong compilation time and should be noted in the footnotes and prefaces of each volume.

Nelson then suggested abbreviating citations. Sampson replied that the Presidential libraries wanted full citations. Kimball left this matter for LaFantasie to take up with his staff. In response to a question from Herring, members of the staff indicated that they had been well treated by the Johnson Library staff.

Keefer raised the problem of the loss of two senior historians and the impending loss of one junior historian, pointing out that the time lag of 6 to 8 months in hiring and the need for 3 months of on the job training meant that the departure of each historian causes the loss in production of one volume. This meant that PA/HO would lose ground in meeting its legally mandated production schedule.

Kimball saw the need to speed up security clearances. Slany said that because of the hiring freeze during the change in administration he was authorized to replace Dave Mabon (who left at the end of February) only last Wednesday. Kimball said that concern should be conveyed to the right people if vacancies will cause a falling behind in meeting the 1996 deadline. Nelson asked whether the Senate Foreign Relations Committee should be informed of this. Kimball said that an appeal should go to the Hill only when there was no alternative. Perkins said that the Office of the Historian has no case because all offices face the same personnel problem. Keefer argued that this Office was unique in that it must produce a tangible product, and noted that the production schedule was predicated on full staffing of the Office.

Nelson said she feared pressure to meet the publication schedule with fewer historians would lead to “cutting corners” on the quality of the volumes. Kimball asked Dr. Slany to investigate the impact of personnel losses on production and report to him in 30 days.

Patterson said that forthcoming subcommittee review of volumes would be helpful. Kimball reasserted that Taylor and Nelson are to look at the first Johnson Administration volume, the one on Arms Control.

Glad suggested the use of temporary employees for expert advice. Kimball pointed out that security clearance delays also applied to hiring temporary employees. Slany gave an example of the use of a retired government employee, Tom Thorne, for his expertise in preparing the Supplement on Intelligence. Rosenberg proposed hiring an extra person to make up for time lost. Slany said that he would try this proposal on Assistant Secretary Donilon. Keefer indicated that this would be difficult because of the policy of reducing government employment. Slany pointed out that this Office has the bulk of the Bureau of Public Affairs budget. Kimball called for use of more historians, if the Office needs them to meet the schedule. He said that if Slany reports slippage in meeting the schedule because of personnel departures, the Advisory Committee would react.

Rosenberg then asked about the effect of page limitations on compilers for the Johnson volumes. Sampson replied that it was easier to compile bigger volumes, but the page allotments for the Cyprus and Western Europe volumes were adequate. Patterson said that the Arms Control volume was about on target in page count. Keefer pointed out that President Johnson was so engrossed with Vietnam that he neglected other topics, except brief crises. Therefore 800 to 1,000 page volumes were feasible. Patterson said that annotation of longer volumes was time consuming. The conclusion was reached that the staff was not terrified by page constraints.

Kimball turned discussion to the Presidential Review Directive on National Security Information. He asked for information for a letter to be drafted by Nelson to an as yet to be determined addressee or addressees (ISOO would get a copy) on the Advisory Committee’s views on the Directive.

Nelson, reading from her notes of Committee members’ discussion at lunch, mentioned that there was no guidance on the public’s right to know and that the membership of the Task Force largely of security officers under the Directive was a disaster. There was no mention of its goals or objectives or of the information user’s participation.

Kimball stated that the Task Force’s work should be open to the public. Glad called for naming the classifiers on documents for the sake of accountability. Kimball pointed out that the authority to classify and declassify was not in the author. Nelson said that periodic downgrading by date was not effective for declassification. Perkins said that the new Executive Order must make the previous Reagan-era order less vague.

Van Camp stated the need to distinguish between historical and contemporary information. The new Executive Order should separate the two. The Working Group in the Department of State on retirement of its 30-year old records should somehow relate to the work of the Presidential Task Force. Kimball agreed with Van Camp that the draft letter should stick to the historical record.

Glad and Rosenberg noted that the statement of objectives included in the Presidential Directive was geared to protecting information, not opening it to the public. In this way the document was skewed to the concerns of the security people.

Kimball said the letter would go to the professional groups with which the Advisory Committee is most effective. He asked Nelson for the draft of the letter within one week. Slany offered to FAX copies to the Committee. Van Camp asked for
different or additional representatives from the Department of State on the Task Force. Kimball said that Assistant Secretary Donilon told Slany he was concerned about the Task Force’s membership as is Assistant Secretary for Administration Pat Kennedy.

Glad asked about Steven Garfinkel, Director of ISOO. Kimball considered Garfinkel as a posssible addressee or recipient of a copy of the proposed letter. Herschler pointed out the June 11 deadline for information to be submitted to the Task Force. Slany asked whether Garfinkel should be invited to the next meeting. Kimball said he would consider it. He asked Nelson to prepare her draft letter within a week and keep it to one page.
The Advisory Committee adjourned into executive session at 2:35 p.m..
